subject: linear_algebra
title: Power Iteration for Dominant Eigenvalue
contentHtml: Power iteration is a simple yet effective method to find the dominant eigenvalue of a square matrix.

problem.statementHtml: Given a square matrix A, find the dominant eigenvalue using power iteration.
hints: Start with an initial guess for x
problem.solutionHtml:
To apply power iteration:

  • Choose an initial vector \mathbf{x}_0
  • Compute \mathbf{y} = A \mathbf{x}_0
  • Update \mathbf{x}_1 = \frac{\mathbf{y}}{||\mathbf{y}||}
  • Repeat steps 2-3 until convergence
problem.answerShort: The dominant eigenvalue is the limit of \lambda_k as k → ∞

workedExample.problemHtml: Find the dominant eigenvalue of matrix A = [[1, 0.5], [0.5, 1]] using power iteration.

steps.explanation: We start with a random vector.
We apply the matrix to our initial vector.
After a few iterations, we converge to the dominant eigenvalue.

intuition: Power iteration works by repeatedly applying the matrix and normalizing the result, effectively amplifying the eigenvector corresponding to the dominant eigenvalue.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Power Iteration: Dominant Eigenvalue
contentHtml: Find the dominant eigenvalue of a matrix using power iteration.

problem.statementHtml: Given a matrix A, find the dominant eigenvalue using power iteration.
hints: Start with an initial guess for the eigenvector.
problem.solutionHtml:
To begin, choose an initial guess \mathbf{v}_0. Then, iterate:

  • Compute \mathbf{v}_k = A \mathbf{v}_{k-1}.
  • Normalize \mathbf{v}_k to have unit length.
problem.answerShort: The dominant eigenvalue is the value that converges.

steps.explanation: Apply the matrix to our initial guess.
Ensure our vector has unit length.

intuition: Power iteration leverages matrix multiplication to converge to the dominant eigenvector.
